org.domainobject.animation.sp.arrayobject

Interface _Memory<T extends ArrayObject>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of array object held in memory
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<T>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    _IndexedMemory<T>, _IndexedMemoryFast<T>, _IndexedMemoryLazy<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    IndexedMemoryLazy

    public interface _Memory<T extends ArrayObject>
extends java.lang.Iterable<T>
    An object that stores array objects and copies them to OpenGL buffers. The process of copying array objects to OpenGL buffers goes by the name of "burning" in this library. Array objects are never burnt directly to the OpenGL buffers. OpenGL buffers are implemented as java.nio.Buffer objects, which are relatively ineffecient for small put operations. Therefore the array objects are first staged in plain arrays and/or java.util.Collection objects, which are then written in one shot to OpenGL memory. Memory objects are intended to be long-lived objects, catering for considerable amounts of array objects. Instantiating them is expensive as it involves the creation of the arrays and/or Collection objects for staging the array objects as well as the creation of java.nio.Buffers to burn the array objects to.
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods

      void add(T arrayObject)
      Add a copy of the specified array object to this memory object.
      ShaderInput burn()
      Burn the internal arrays and/or Collection objects to OpenGL memory.
      void clear()
      Put the memory object into a state where you can start adding array objects again as though the memory object was just created.

      Create a new array object of type T.

    • Method Detail

      • size

        int size()
        Get the number of array objects stored in memory.
        Returns:
        The number of array objects stored in memory

      • add

        void add(T arrayObject)
        Add a copy of the specified array object to this memory object. The array object passed to this method is read only.
        Parameters:
        arrayObject - The array object to copy into memory

      • newInstance

        T newInstance()
        Create a new array object of type T. The new array object will occupy a small portion of this memory object's backing array. Thus, you will receive a new instance of type T, but no array creation or array copying takes places. With the "fast" implementations of _Memory you must call ArrayObject.commit() on the array objects created through newInstance(). Otherwise they will not be visible to the burn process. Also, the memory's object counter (reflected by the size() method) will not be updated until you call ArrayObject.commit(). When using the "lazy" or "non-indexed" implementations of _Memory you don't need to call ArrayObject.commit(). It's a no-op in that case (as is ArrayObject#discard()).
        Returns:
        A new array object of type T
        See Also:
        #commit(), burn(), #discard()

      • burn

        ShaderInput burn()
        Burn the internal arrays and/or Collection objects to OpenGL memory. Whether or not these internal structures still are still intact after burning is implementation-dependent.
        Returns:

      • clear

        void clear()
        Put the memory object into a state where you can start adding array objects again as though the memory object was just created. Most likely this will just reset some internal counters without actually clearing the internal structures, but this is implementation-dependent.
